Alright, so this is the paper from 10 years ago.
Ontologies are US unified model for social networks and semantics.
Sample of what happens when your PhD advisor takes his eyes off you for a month or two and you start thinking about some of the things that that bother you about the semantic web.
And one of these things is really this notion of of ontologies as being shared, agreed, conceptualizations.
The problem with that is the notion of ontologies at the time didn't really account for this dimension of being shared by a community.
But this paper tries to do is really account for this social dimension of ontologies by extending the traditional model of of classifications of instances into concepts with a third dimension.
And that is the dimension of the actors who are sharing those conceptualizations.

What it also does, is it connected to this notion of folksonomies, which are social tagging systems were sort of this kind of data and naturally appears these are systems where users are tagging items with concepts and you can track essentially who used which concept on which item.
What it does further is it collects some data and then it tries to to apply particular methods to extract some of the implicit knowledge that are that are present in folksonomies.
The.
Tickler method is perhaps not so interesting.

You can read the paper to to get the details, but what it does is it takes some venom methods from social network analysis, in particular the analysis of affiliation networks and applies it to this to this tripartite graph of actors, concepts and instances.
What this guy?

In the end, is really two different kinds of networks of concepts, one that is induced by items being classified together under under the same concepts and the other one is generated by essentially the network of of actors sharing concepts on particular items.

The paper then collect some some real data actually from from delicious then popular social tagging system and also generate some artificial data by looking off at Co occurrences of person names and concepts on the web.
Then the paper goes on and shows that these two networks are actually quite different in their characteristics.
They have different use cases in terms of mining, certain linguistic associations or in terms of mining more semantic topical associations.
I looked at a little bit about the impact of the paper.
What you can see is that it sort of reached its its highest impact around around 2008.
You can also see the top citing authors if your name is on this list.
I definitely owe you a beer because the paper altogether gathered over 720 citations, which is really nice to see as an author.
What I also did is is to get a little bit deeper into into what people have done with this paper, which I think is is probably a very interesting exercise for for everyone.
There are two ways to do this if you're using Microsoft academic Search, you can look at the citation context of the citing papers, but I also just read some of the some of the papers.
The top 20 papers by my citations.
It was really interesting to see.

Sort of the diversity of the of the work that appeared following the publication of this paper, and and it really, it really shows that probably paper open more questions than it actually answered in terms of in terms of expanding semantic web research, it really led to some some thinking about emergent semantics in general, or collective intelligence.
As somebody follow up, works called it.
This related imports to modeling to two representations of of dynamic ontologies.
Also, you know the processes that might lead to like to emergence in certain circumstances.
It also led to new methods for mining folksonomies for extracting, extracting hierarchies of concepts, frequent itemsets Association rules and many other types of types of knowledge.
But it also did by bringing methods from from sort of social network analysis.
It opened up a little bit to the community that was interested in either social web data or or using using methods from from concept complex networks, for example.
It also inspired some applications that went beyond ontology engineering, so the original paper really focused on on on that aspect.

But people have taken some of the ideas and used it to create better social tagging recommendation systems or use it in personalized search and recommendations of multimedia items or documents on the web.

Ontologies are US unified model for social networks and semantics.
Sample of what happens when your PhD advisor takes his eyes off you for a month or two and you start thinking about some of the things that that bother you about the semantic web.
And one of these things is really this notion of of ontologies as being shared, agreed, conceptualizations.
The problem with that is the notion of ontologies at the time didn't really account for this dimension of being shared by a community.
But this paper tries to do is really account for this social dimension of ontologies by extending the traditional model of of classifications of instances into concepts with a third dimension.
And that is the dimension of the actors who are sharing those conceptualizations.

What it also does, is it connected to this notion of folksonomies, which are social tagging systems were sort of this kind of data and naturally appears these are systems where users are tagging items with concepts and you can track essentially who used which concept on which item.
What it does further is it collects some data and then it tries to to apply particular methods to extract some of the implicit knowledge that are that are present in folksonomies.
